Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 185A and the court’s jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes and related tort and contract claims.

Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits the landlord from unreasonably interfering with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits the landlord from unreasonably interfering with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or frame the landlord’s obligations in those terms. Instead, it expressly abandons constructive eviction and adopts an implied warranty of habitability, treating the lease as a contract and focusing on safe, clean, and habitable premises. While unreasonable interference with use and enjoyment is implicit in the facts, the case’s doctrinal basis is habitability, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment, so it does not directly support the stated proposition.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will.

Hernandez v. California Federal Bank, 12.raw_text: Hernandez v. California Federal Bank, 120 Cal.App.4th 715 (2004)
Hernandez v. California Federal Bank, 12.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibits the landlord from unreasonably interfering with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Hernandez v. California Federal Bank, 12.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a procedural decision about continuances on a summary judgment motion and does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Nowhere does the court discuss or articulate any rule about a landlord’s interference with a tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of leased premises. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the stated proposition about the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Hernandez v. California Federal Bank, 12.relevant_excerpt: The opinion contains no discussion of landlord-tenant relationships or the covenant of quiet enjoyment; it is focused on whether the trial court abused its discretion in denying a continuance under Code of Civil Procedure section 437c, subdivision (h), due to counsel’s serious illness.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws and regulations also establish minimum standards for residential housing and authorize local boards of health and the Department of Public Health to adopt and enforce the State Sanitary Code.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: Under these standards and related law, landlords have duties to maintain units free from conditions hazardous to health (including mold and water intrusion) and to supply repairs to keep premises fit for habitation.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 111, \u00a7127A.proposition: Under these standards and related law, landlords have duties to maintain units free from conditions hazardous to health (including mold and water intrusion) and to supply repairs to keep premises fit for habitation.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186.proposition: Additionally, Massachusetts law (Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 and related authorities) and case law place responsibilities on landlords to provide premises in a habitable condition and to not interfere with tenants’ possession or use.

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.raw_text: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: Leading cases and authorities on quiet enjoyment, habitability, and landlord obligations (representative, persuasive authority):
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly traces the evolution from the traditional covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction to the modern implied warranty of habitability and recasts residential leases as contracts for shelter and services. It interprets and applies New York’s Real Property Law § 235-b, articulates the landlord’s nondelegable duty to maintain habitable premises, and ties the tenant’s rent obligation to habitability, making it a leading authority on habitability, landlord obligations, and the relationship to quiet enjoyment. Thus it squarely supports citing it as a leading case on these doctrines.
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.relevant_excerpt: “Initially by judicial decision … and ultimately by legislative enactment in August, 1975, the obsolete doctrine of the lease as a conveyance of land was discarded. Codifying existing case law, the enactment of section 235-b of the Real Property Law … [means] A residential lease is now effectively deemed a sale of shelter and services by the landlord who impliedly warrants: first, that the premises are fit for human habitation; second, that the condition of the premises is in accord with the uses reasonably intended by the parties; and, third, that the tenants are not subjected to any conditions endangering or detrimental to their life, health or safety.”

Robinson v. Lisowski, 78 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Robinson v. Lisowski, 78 Mass. App. Ct. ___
Robinson v. Lisowski, 78 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Leading cases and authorities on quiet enjoyment, habitability, and landlord obligations (representative, persuasive authority):

Ames v. Mayo, 145 Mass. 180.proposition: Leading cases and authorities on quiet enjoyment, habitability, and landlord obligations (representative, persuasive authority):
Ames v. Mayo, 145 Mass. 180.support_reasoning: The case concerns a covenant against encumbrances in a deed and the inadmissibility of parol evidence to vary that written covenant. It does not address quiet enjoyment, habitability, or landlord obligations, nor does it involve a landlord–tenant relationship. Therefore, it does not support the proposition for which it is being cited.
Ames v. Mayo, 145 Mass. 180.relevant_excerpt: “This is an action of contract on a covenant against incumbrances in a deed from the defendant to the plaintiff… The defendant offered to prove, by parol testimony, that, at the time the deed was given, and as a part of the consideration, the plaintiff promised to pay said assessment. This evidence was rightly rejected. It directly varied and contradicted the written contract of the defendant.”
